title: Occipital Neuralgia
scope: ** Evaluation and management of occipital neuralgia in adults. Includes ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria, differentiation from migraine/tension-type/cervicogenic headache, diagnostic and therapeutic nerve blocks, pharmacotherapy, and interventional procedures. Covers ED acute management, inpatient evaluation for refractory cases, outpatient chronic management, and ICU considerations for severe refractory pain or post-procedural monitoring. Excludes primary headache disorders unless part of differential.

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute occipital pain; diagnostic confirmation per ICHD-3 criteria

doseOptions.orderSentence: Greater occipital nerve (GON) block - diagnostic/therapeutic 2-3 mL SC/deep

dosing.instructions: 2% lidocaine (2-3 mL) OR 0.5% bupivacaine (2-3 mL) injected at medial third of line between external occipital protuberance and mastoid process; aspirate before injection; may add methylprednisolone 40 mg or triamcinolone 20-40 mg

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Pain relief onset (lidocaine 5-10 min; bupivacaine 15-30 min); monitor for vasovagal reaction, hematoma

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Pain in LON distribution (lateral occiput, behind ear)

Second-Line/Refractory Treatment.indication: Neuropathic pain; coexisting depression or anxiety; alternative to duloxetine

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily x 1 week; increase to 75 mg daily; target 75-150 mg daily; max 225 mg/day

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.indication: Confirmed occipital neuralgia with positive diagnostic block; recurrent episodes

doseOptions.orderSentence: GON block with steroid (ultrasound-guided) (CPT 64405, 76942) 2-3 mL SC/deep

dosing.instructions: 0.5% bupivacaine 2-3 mL + methylprednisolone 40 mg (or triamcinolone 40 mg); US-guided for precision; landmark: medial third of line from external occipital protuberance to mastoid process; repeat q4-8 weeks as needed (limit 3-4 steroid injections per year)
dosing.orderSentence: GON block with steroid (ultrasound-guided) (CPT 64405, 76942) 2-3 mL SC/deep

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.contraindications: Active infection, coagulopathy, allergy to injectate
Interventional/Procedural Treatment.monitoring: Pain scores, duration of relief, steroid side effects (skin atrophy, glucose elevation in diabetics)

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.indication: Refractory to peripheral nerve blocks; suspected C2 root origin

doseOptions.orderSentence: C2 nerve root block (fluoroscopy-guided) 1-2 mL Perineural

dosing.instructions: 0.5% bupivacaine 1-2 mL +/- dexamethasone 4 mg; fluoroscopy-guided with contrast confirmation; performed by interventional pain specialist or neuroradiologist
dosing.orderSentence: C2 nerve root block (fluoroscopy-guided) 1-2 mL Perineural

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.contraindications: Active infection, coagulopathy, vertebral artery anomaly
Interventional/Procedural Treatment.monitoring: Post-procedure neurologic exam; monitor for vertebral artery injury, spinal cord injury, high spinal block

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.item: Pulsed radiofrequency ablation (PRF) of GON or C2 dorsal root ganglion
Interventional/Procedural Treatment.indication: Refractory occipital neuralgia; positive diagnostic block but short-lived relief from repeated injections

doseOptions.orderSentence: Pulsed radiofrequency ablation (PRF) of GON or C2 dorsal root ganglion N/A Percutaneous

dosing.instructions: 42 degrees C, 120 seconds x 2-3 cycles; fluoroscopy or US-guided needle placement at GON or C2 DRG; performed by pain specialist; non-destructive (pulsed, not thermal)
dosing.orderSentence: Pulsed radiofrequency ablation (PRF) of GON or C2 dorsal root ganglion N/A Percutaneous

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.contraindications: Active infection, coagulopathy, implanted cardiac device near field
Interventional/Procedural Treatment.monitoring: Post-procedure pain assessment; monitor for numbness, dysesthesia, infection

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.indication: Suspected C1-C2 facet-mediated pain contributing to occipital neuralgia

doseOptions.orderSentence: C1-C2 (atlantoaxial) facet joint injection 0.5-1 mL Intra-articular

dosing.instructions: 0.5% bupivacaine 0.5-1 mL + triamcinolone 20 mg; fluoroscopy-guided with contrast arthrogram; performed by interventional pain specialist
dosing.orderSentence: C1-C2 (atlantoaxial) facet joint injection 0.5-1 mL Intra-articular

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.contraindications: Active infection, coagulopathy, vertebral artery anomaly
Interventional/Procedural Treatment.monitoring: Pain response; vertebral artery injury risk; infection

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.indication: Medically refractory occipital neuralgia; failed 3+ medication classes and interventional procedures; significant functional impairment

dosing.instructions: Percutaneous trial (5-7 days) first; if >50% pain relief, proceed to permanent implant; leads placed transversely across the occiput at C1 level; requires multidisciplinary evaluation and psychological screening

Interventional/Procedural Treatment.contraindications: Active infection, coagulopathy, inability to manage device, untreated psychiatric comorbidity
Interventional/Procedural Treatment.monitoring: Device function, lead migration, infection, battery life; pain scores; follow-up at 1, 3, 6, 12 months then annually

Referrals & Consults.indication: Diagnostic uncertainty; refractory to initial treatment; consideration of interventional procedures
Candidate for fluoroscopy/US-guided nerve blocks, PRF, or neurostimulation
Cervical muscle dysfunction, postural contributors, myofascial trigger points
Structural compression (Arnold-Chiari, posterior fossa lesion); consideration for occipital nerve decompression
Suspected autoimmune etiology (RA with C1-C2 subluxation, lupus)
Chronic pain with coexisting depression, anxiety, or catastrophizing; pre-implant psychological evaluation for ONS
Visual symptoms suggesting GCA; papilledema on fundoscopy; evaluate for secondary causes

Patient Instructions.item: Avoid prolonged neck flexion (phone, computer) and sustained postures; take breaks every 30 minutes
Patient Instructions.rationale: Postural strain exacerbates occipital nerve irritation

Patient Instructions.item: Apply warm compresses to suboccipital region for 15-20 minutes, 3-4 times daily
Patient Instructions.rationale: Muscle relaxation; reduces spasm-related nerve compression

Patient Instructions.item: Perform gentle cervical stretching exercises as directed by physical therapy
Patient Instructions.rationale: Reduces muscle tension; improves cervical mobility

Patient Instructions.item: Avoid tight headwear, helmets, or hairstyles that compress the occipital region
Patient Instructions.rationale: External compression is a known trigger for occipital neuralgia

Patient Instructions.item: Keep a headache diary recording frequency, severity (0-10), triggers, and medication use
Patient Instructions.rationale: Tracks treatment response; identifies triggers and patterns

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if sudden severe headache ("thunderclap"), fever, neck stiffness, vision changes, weakness, or numbness
Patient Instructions.rationale: Red flags for secondary causes (SAH, meningitis, vertebral artery dissection)

Patient Instructions.item: Take medications exactly as prescribed; do not abruptly stop gabapentin, pregabalin, carbamazepine, or baclofen
Patient Instructions.rationale: Abrupt discontinuation risks withdrawal seizures and rebound pain

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Complete ergonomic workstation assessment and modification
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Reduces prolonged cervical strain; corrects forward head posture

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Use cervical pillow and maintain neutral cervical alignment during sleep
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Improper sleep position compresses occipital nerves; maintain neutral cervical alignment

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Engage in stress reduction techniques (mindfulness, biofeedback, cognitive behavioral therapy)
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Stress and muscle tension exacerbate occipital neuralgia; CBT shown effective for chronic pain

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes, 5 days/week)
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Central pain modulation; improves overall pain tolerance; reduces comorbid depression

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Limit caffeine intake to <200 mg/day and avoid abrupt caffeine withdrawal
Lifestyle & Prevention.rationale: Caffeine withdrawal can trigger headache exacerbation; excessive use contributes to medication overuse

differential.features: Pulsating quality, unilateral frontotemporal predominance, photophobia/phonophobia, nausea/vomiting, aura; attacks 4-72 hours
differential.tests: ICHD-3 criteria; migraine does not respond to occipital nerve block (or response is incidental due to overlap)

differential.features: Bilateral, pressing/tightening quality, mild-moderate intensity, no nausea; pericranial tenderness
differential.tests: Clinical criteria; typically holocephalic rather than occipital; no lancinating quality

differential.features: Unilateral, non-throbbing; reduced cervical ROM; pain provoked by neck movement or sustained postures; referred from C1-C3
differential.tests: Diagnostic cervical medial branch block; MRI cervical spine; pain is referred (not neuralgic); does not follow specific nerve distribution

differential.features: Neck pain radiating to occiput; may have dermatomal sensory loss; motor weakness rare
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (C1-C2 pathology); EMG/NCS; C2 selective nerve root block

differential.features: Occipital headache provoked by Valsalva, cough, or straining; may have cerebellar signs, syringomyelia
differential.tests: MRI brain and cervical spine (cerebellar tonsil descent >5 mm below foramen magnum)

differential.features: Progressive headache, worse in morning; nausea/vomiting; papilledema; cerebellar signs
differential.tests: MRI brain with contrast; fundoscopic exam

differential.features: Sudden severe occipital/neck pain; may have Horner syndrome, lateral medullary signs, stroke symptoms
differential.tests: CTA neck; MRA with fat suppression; onset is acute/sudden

differential.features: Age >50; jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, visual changes; elevated ESR/CRP; temporal artery tenderness
differential.tests: ESR, CRP (markedly elevated); temporal artery biopsy; temporal artery ultrasound (halo sign)

differential.features: Strictly unilateral periorbital/temporal pain; autonomic features (lacrimation, ptosis, rhinorrhea); attacks 15-180 min; circadian periodicity
differential.tests: ICHD-3 criteria; autonomic features absent in occipital neuralgia; different pain distribution

evidence.recommendation: ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria for occipital neuralgia (13.4): pain in distribution of occipital nerves, tenderness over nerve, temporary relief with anesthetic block
evidence.source: [Headache Classification Committee of the IHS. Cephalalgia 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29368949/)

evidence.recommendation: Greater occipital nerve block is both diagnostic and therapeutic for occipital neuralgia; positive response supports the diagnosis
Gabapentin and pregabalin are effective for neuropathic pain including occipital neuralgia
OnabotulinumtoxinA injection in occipital region reduces pain in refractory occipital neuralgia
evidence.source: Choi I, Laurito CE. Curr Pain Headache Rep 2011

evidence.recommendation: Pulsed radiofrequency of C2 dorsal root ganglion provides sustained relief in refractory occipital neuralgia
evidence.source: [Vanderhoek MD et al. Anesth Pain Med 2013](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24282778/)

evidence.recommendation: Occipital nerve stimulation for medically intractable occipital neuralgia: systematic review shows moderate efficacy
Tricyclic antidepressants (amitriptyline, nortriptyline) are effective for neuropathic pain; NNT approximately 3.6
evidence.source: [Moore RA et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26146793/)

evidence.recommendation: Carbamazepine is effective for paroxysmal neuralgic pain; first-line for trigeminal neuralgia, used for occipital neuralgia with lancinating character
evidence.source: [Di Stefano G et al. Expert Rev Neurother 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28829200/)

evidence.recommendation: Ultrasound-guided occipital nerve blocks improve accuracy and efficacy compared to landmark technique
evidence.source: [Shim JH et al. Korean J Anesthesiol 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21860751/)

evidence.recommendation: Cervicogenic headache must be differentiated from occipital neuralgia; diagnostic cervical medial branch blocks are the gold standard

monitoring.action: Adjust medication dose; consider interventional procedure
If short-lived, consider PRF or repeat with steroid; if no response, reconsider diagnosis

monitoring.frequency: q2wk x 2 months, then q3 months
monitoring.action: Hold carbamazepine if WBC <3000 or ANC <1500 or platelets <100K; hematology referral
Reduce dose or switch agent if hyponatremia
Reduce dose or discontinue if transaminases >3x ULN
Reduce dose or discontinue if QTc prolonged or new conduction abnormality
Medication adjustment; consider interventional procedure if worsening

monitoring.item: Blood pressure (if on duloxetine or venlafaxine)
monitoring.action: Reduce dose or switch agent if sustained hypertension

disposition.criteria: Diagnosis confirmed by clinical features and/or positive diagnostic nerve block; pain controlled with oral medications; no red flags; outpatient follow-up arranged within 2-4 weeks

Intractable pain despite ED nerve block and parenteral analgesics; need for IV medications or serial nerve blocks; diagnostic uncertainty requiring urgent imaging; suspected secondary cause (dissection, mass)

Suspected vertebral artery dissection with neurologic deficits; post-procedural complication requiring close monitoring; hemodynamic instability related to pain crisis or anaphylaxis from procedural agents
All patients with new diagnosis of occipital neuralgia; medication titration and monitoring; assessment of treatment response at 4-6 weeks
Failed 2+ oral medication trials at adequate doses; recurrent need for nerve blocks (>3 per year); candidate for PRF, botulinum toxin, or neurostimulation evaluation
Structural lesion identified (Chiari malformation, posterior fossa mass, C1-C2 pathology requiring surgical intervention); occipital nerve decompression consideration
Medication management for stable patients; metabolic monitoring (labs for carbamazepine, gabapentin renal dosing); annual reassessment of treatment plan
